statement:
When $a,b,c,d$ are complex numbers and $z$ is a complex number such that
$-\pi < \arg (-z) < +\pi$ and $C$ is a contour in the complex $s$-plane
which goes from $-i \infty$ to $+ i \infty$ chosen such that the poles
of $\Gamma (a+s) \Gamma (b+s)$ lie to the left of $C$ and the poles of
$\Gamma (-s)$ lie to the right of $C$, then
$$\int_C {\Gamma (a+s) \Gamma (b+s) \over \Gamma (c+s)}
\Gamma (-s) (-z)^s \, ds = 
2 \pi i {\Gamma (a) \Gamma (b) \over \Gamma (c)} F (a, b; c; z)$$
names: Barnes' integral representation of the  hypergeometric function
